text: Robots today move conservatively, using control systems that maintain full control authority at all times. Humans and animals move aggressively by executing motions that lose instantaneous control authority. Controlling nonlinear systems without complete control authority requires methods that exploit the natural dynamics of machines. This course discusses nonlinear dynamics and control of underactuated mechanical systems, emphasizing machine learning methods. Topics include nonlinear dynamics of passive robots (walkers, swimmers, flyers), motion planning, partial feedback linearization, energy-shaping control, analytical optimal control, reinforcement learning/approximate optimal control, and the influence of mechanical design on control. Examples from biology include legged locomotion, compliant manipulation, underwater robots, and flying machines.

text: This course studies basic optimization and the principles of optimal control. It considers deterministic and stochastic problems for both discrete and continuous systems. The course covers solution methods including numerical search algorithms, model predictive control, dynamic programming, variational calculus, and approaches based on Pontryagin’s maximum principle, and it includes many examples and applications of the theory.

text: This course provides an overview of robot mechanisms, dynamics, and intelligent controls. Topics include planar and spatial kinematics and motion planning; mechanism design for manipulators and mobile robots; multi‑rigid‑body dynamics and 3D graphic simulation; control design, actuators, and sensors; wireless networking, task modeling, human–machine interface, and embedded software. Weekly laboratories provide experience with servo drives, real‑time control, and embedded software. Students will design and fabricate working robotic systems in a group‑based term project.

This course introduces fundamental algorithmic approaches for creating robot systems that can autonomously manipulate physical objects in unstructured environments such as homes and restaurants. Topics include perception (including approaches based on deep learning and 3D geometry), planning (robot kinematics and trajectory generation, collision‑free motion planning, task‑and‑motion planning, and planning under uncertainty), as well as dynamics and control, both model‑based and learning‑based. Homework assignments guide students through building a software stack to enable a robotic arm to autonomously manipulate objects in cluttered scenes. A final project lets students explore a specific aspect in depth.

text: The course addresses dynamic systems—systems that evolve with time. These systems have inputs and outputs, and it is important to understand how the input affects the output or what inputs should be given to generate a desired output. The focus is on systems modeled by ordinary differential equations (ODEs) that satisfy linearity and time‑invariance. The course analyzes system responses to inputs and initial conditions and examines interconnections such as feedback. Students learn how to design control systems that ensure desirable properties like stability and performance for the interconnection with a given dynamic system.

text: The book is dedicated to helping undergraduate students understand the basic concepts, theory, and applications of robotics and control, including kinematics of manipulators and end effector design. Specific robot applications including an autonomous sumo robot, combat robot, and micromouse robot are introduced. The control‑related content covers state‑space, flow diagrams, linear quadratic regulator (LQR) controller, model predictive control, and full state feedback control. It is expected that the book will offer students a convenient reference to learn robotics and control techniques. text: Chemical Process Dynamics and Controls is an open textbook that covers a wide range of topics related to process dynamics and control. The book is extensive and includes material on statistics, instrumentation, piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs), and chemical process control. It is available under a Creative Commons Attribution license (CC BY).

section_title: Controls Engineering in the FIRST Robotics Competition
text: Controls Engineering in the FIRST Robotics Competition introduces control theory to high school students. The book covers fundamental concepts such as block diagrams, gain, and the difference between open‑ and closed‑loop systems, and later chapters discuss PID control, calculus, linear algebra, and robotics applications. The book is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution‑ShareAlike 4.0 license.

section_title: Interactive MATLAB based project learning in a robotics course
text: This paper describes efforts to deploy an interactive project‑based learning approach for a robotics course using MATLAB. The graduate‑level course combines theoretical and practical aspects through laboratory sessions and a class project. Labs illustrate modeling, simulation, path planning, and control using the Robotics Toolbox under MATLAB and interaction with physical robot platforms. The class project has two tasks: controlling a 5‑degree‑of‑freedom robot manipulator to perform pick‑and‑place tasks with objects moved from initial to target poses using MATLAB simulations, and using a vision system to enable an autonomous robotic arm to pick colored objects and place them in different poses based on their colors. Course results showed that high‑level deployment of robot platforms in interactive project‑based learning increased student performance, with 100% success in the first task and 75% success in the second task. Assessment rubrics evaluated report and presentation quality (30%), accuracy of the final pose (35%), execution speed (20%), motion smoothness (15%), and a bonus vision‑based task (10%). The article is open access under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 license.

text: Cognitive Robotics & Control is an open access book that highlights emerging applications and recent breakthroughs in cognitive robotics and control. It discusses knowledge processing and generation for autonomous systems and covers procedures, algorithms, architectures, and implementations for reasoning, problem solving, and decision making in robotics and control. The book is © 2020 by the authors and is published under a CC BY‑NC‑ND license.

This course provides an introduction to linear systems, transfer functions, and Laplace transforms. It covers stability and feedback and provides basic design tools for specifying transient response. The course also briefly covers frequency‑domain techniques. The course materials are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution‑NonCommercial‑ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

section_title: Feedback Systems: An Introduction for Scientists and Engineers
text: Feedback Systems: An Introduction for Scientists and Engineers is an open textbook that covers system modeling, analysis, and controller design. According to the FBSwiki, content is available under a Creative Commons Attribution‑NonCommercial‑ShareAlike license unless otherwise noted. The table of contents includes chapters on modeling, linearization, stability, frequency domain analysis, state feedback, and controller design.
